item.title: Report E-2025060385
item.description:
Report E-2025060385

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-18
  • City: Marianna
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SEABOARD MARINE, LTD., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 50000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Truck Driver 1169 reported container GESU672757-9 leaking after driver had stopped at a TA Travel Center (2112 FL-71, Mariana, FL 32448) to fuel. The container was confirmed to be carrying 18 IBC totes of (UN1760, CORROSIVE LIQUID, N.O.S. (AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE, SODIUM HYDROXIDE), CLASS 8, PG II), loaded and sealed by shipper Cytec Industries Technology Solutions at their warehouse, and picked up by driver 1169 earlier that day. Following the initial report, the container was moved to an isolated area of the truck stop, and 911 was contacted. Jackson County police and fire departments responded to the scene; fire department proceeded to cut the seal and enter the container to assess the situation. A.C.T. Environmental was contracted to respond and provide clean-up and disposal services, arriving onsite at approximately 1900 and completing the clean-up at approximately 0600 the following morning (6/19/25). The leak was confirmed to come from one of the IBCs which appeared to have been punctured by a sharp object (potentially a forklift during loading) on one of the sides near the bottom of the IBC.

  • Description: At 14:34 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO (BIN) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to improper loading, an unknown amount of Simiron - U-Tint Universal Pigment Packs (hazardous - UN1090) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable cleaning the release donning the proper PPE per SDS. The released product,18 damaged cans, and oil-dri will be placed into a 25-gallon poly drum and staged in OS&D.

  • Description: At 12:24 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO (USU about a cargo release. It was reported that due to a nail puncture from the pallet, approximately .25 gallon of ABELION BM50 (hazardous - UN2735) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor and dock. The terminal advised they already cleaned and contained the release. The released product, damaged jug and oil-dry were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum and staged in OS&D. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release.

item.title: Report E-2025070391
item.description:
Report E-2025070391

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-18
  • City: EAST SYRACUSE
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10918
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâs arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 600ft-by-1ft area of concrete between the trailer and soil and a 5ft-by-5ft area of soil and estimated that fifty-five (55) gallons of material was released from one (1) 55-gallon poly drum due to the drum being forked. Before the contractor arrived, the facility personnel placed the leaking drum into one (1) 95-gallon steel drum with the top cut off that already contained other absorbent materials. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizer to the affected areas. It was determined that a strip of one foot away along the concrete was going to need to be excavated. Seven (7) 55-gallon poly drums of contaminated soil and impacted absorbents were generated. The drums began bulging and it was advised that containment will need to be established around the drums, and they will need to be left outside to vent. The lids were loosened and covered with poly sheeting. The waste was staged onsite before contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâs arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10ft-by-30ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that twenty-five (25) gallons of material were released from one (1) 55-gallon steel drum. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents. After the absorbents were collected up, a neutral soap was applied to the affected areas and then pressure washed. Petroleum distillates impacted water, and granular absorbents were containerized into three (3) 55-gallon metal drums. ESTES reviewed all work before contractor demobilization. The generated waste was staged onsite and will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal

  • City: DRACUT
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO ENTERPRISE SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 09:06 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release at terminal XNB. It was reported that approximately 2 gallons of Battery Acid released from two 2050-pound batteries due to falling over while in transit due to being improperly secured. The release impacted trailer #3216309 at dock #56. Call Center reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site, the terminal has requested contractor dispatch. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of UN2794 Batteries, wet, filled with Acid to area of the wooden trailer floor due to improper loading. The crew neutralized the trailer floor with an acid eater. The damaged batteries were up righted and secured to a new pallet. The neutralized battery acid impacted absorbents were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On June 18, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1993 was forked and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel placed the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon salvage drum. FCE personnel utilized hand tools to collect all spent absorbents for waste, then used absorbent pads and cleaning agents to wipe down the impacted surfaces of the trailer and any undamaged freight. All spent absorbents and any cleanup debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Description: At 00:52 AM ET, XKC contacted the call center to report a spill that was found inside of a trailer in Kansas City, KS. The spill consists of approximately 25 pounds of Sodium Nitrate Prills, which released from 3â50-pound plastic bags due to not being properly packaged by the shipper, causing them to tear during transit and spill onto the trailer floor. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed spill had already been cleaned up by XPO personnel of UN1498 Sodium Nitrate Prills product due to not being properly packaged by shipper. The damaged bags were containerized to an 85-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2025070187
item.description:
Report E-2025070187

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-17
  • City: JACKSONVILLE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANGER TRANSPORT CORP.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our driver delivered a bulk load of Butyl Cellosolve Solvent to Axalta Coatings in Jacksonville, Texas. The driver used his pump and hoses to offload the shipment from our tank trailer into the customers storage tank. During the unloading process a leak developed due to an undetected cut in one of our discharge hoses and product poured onto the ground. Our driver immediately shut the interval on the trailer contained the spill. The customer then cleaned used an in house crew to clean up the material the was on the ground. The driver used a different hose and offloaded the rest of the product that was in the trailer. The hose that failed was previously inspected by our shop and showed no signs of any defects. The hose failed because there was an undetected cut in it. When the driver returned back to the terminal the hose was inspected and discarded. We have spoken to the driver and asked him to make sure that he inspects his hoses more thoroughly.

Crews containerized one (1) damaged 55-gallon drum of UN2672, all spent absorbents, and PPE into one (1) overpack drum.

  • Description: On June 17, 2025, two (2) 55-pound bags of UN2680 fell in transit and released approximately twenty (20) pounds of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized hand tools to collect the released product, then used absorbent pads and cleaning agents to wipe down the dock floor. The damaged bags were placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum, and the collected product and miscellaneous waste were collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon pail.

item.title: Report X-2025061340
item.description:
Report X-2025061340

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-16
  • City: LA FERIA
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Two pails arrived crushed from freight shift to 129 from Dallas. One of the pails was empty by the time they arrived. The operations supervisor advised that the pails were creased and did not appear to be damaged from a forklift strike so he was sure it was from the load shift. The operations superv isor also advised that the damaged pails were UN1866. Safety advised CURA would be contacted for remediation. Crews proceeded to unload the trailer, downstack the impacted pallet, and they observed a total two of (2) 5-gallon pails of resin solution (UN1866) had been damaged, so crews removed them f or waste. E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents to the released product in the trailer and swept them in with hand tools. Crews wiped down the impacted freight, pallet, and trailer with absorbent pads and cleaning agents, and restacked the undamaged freight for further shipment and processing. A ll spent absorbents and any miscellaneous cleanup debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and the damaged pails were all collected and containerized into one (1) other 55-gallon drum. Both drums of waste were labeled appropriately and staged in the terminal's waste holdi ng room.

  • Description: ABF Operation Supervisor states that they opened up trailer 552565 in dock door 9 when they found a pallet of UN2880, CALCIUM HYPOCHLORITE, HYDRATED, 5.1, PG II, RQ, CALCIUM that had not been shrink wrapped properly and fell onto another hazmat shipment of UN2014, HYDROGEN PEROXIDE, AQUEOUS SOLUTION S, 5.1 (8), PG II resulting in 5 fl oz of the spill to foam up on the trailer floor. ABF Supervisor states that none of it hit the yard. ABF Supervisor states that the freight had also not been properly blocked or braced for the UN2880 hazmat pallet which is what resulted in the spill to occur. ABF Supervisor states that a really small amount of both hazmats did make contact but a majority of it was still sealed. Safety advised supervisor to block the spill off from it spreading additionally until CURA arrived on-site to clean it. Safety contacted CURA and they're dispatch someone on emergency response for cleanup.

item.title: Report E-2025070372
item.description:
Report E-2025070372

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-15
  • City: MURDO
  • State: SD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: INGENIUM GROUP, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 950000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On June 15th 2025, Ingenium experienced a trailer fire while transporting hazardous waste eastbound on Interstate 90. The incident occurred on the off-ramp at mile marker 191, temporarily blocking access. The fire originated in the rear section of the trailer. According to the driverâs report, the incident began with a tire blowout, followed by a second blowout on the rear axle. The Automatic Valve System (AVS) failed to engage; likely due to damage from debris or the tire failure, causing the brakes to lock and overheat. This overheating generated sparks that are believed to have ignited the underside of the trailer. Ingenium contacted and reported the incident to NRC (NRC# 1434197) when immediately available to do so. The fire resulted in the partial destruction of manifested hazardous waste. Emergency responders, including the Murdo Volunteer Fire Department and Murdo Police Department, were immediately dispatched. Ingenium coordinated with its emergency response contractor, Ambipar (North Dakota), and worked alongside local and state authorities to secure the scene and begin cleanup operations. Initial field assessments indicate that the majority of the damage occurred in the rear section of the trailer, which contained waste associated with Systech manifests. While many containers remained intact, all materials were transferred to new containers or salvage drums as a precaution. Due to the extent of the incident, the waste shipments could not be delivered to the originally designated facilities (TSDFs) as planned. A portion of the waste was destroyed in the fire. The remaining materials were recovered, secured, and segregated for proper management. These recovered materials were subsequently shipped to an alternate permitted facility for identification, profiling, and compliant handling. All recovered waste is being managed under EPA ID SDR000222927 (Ingenium Group, LLC) in accordance with Episodic Event reporting protocols, as the materials are now considered commingled with other manifested waste from the same trailer. Regulatory notifications were submitted to: Oregon DEQ Hazardous Waste Program Washington State Department of Ecology Impacted manifest numbers include: 000554545DAT, 000554550DAT, 000554552DAT, 000554555DAT, 000556777DAT, 000554526DAT, 000554528DAT, 000554537DAT, 000554540DAT, 000554544DAT, 000554548DAT, 000554551DAT, 000554553DAT, 000554556DAT, 000554573DAT, 000554583DAT, 000556767DAT, 000556769DAT, 000556775DAT, and 000556782DAT. EPA Waste Codes Involved: D001, D002, D004âD008, D010, D011, D035, F003, F005. Ingenium assumed full ownership of all hazardous materials on the trailer and subsequently obtained a temporary EPA Site ID for the fire location to facilitate proper management and reporting. Per the South Dakota Department of Agriculture, Ingenium conducted excavation of areas potentially impacted by runoff from firefighting activities. These areas will be backfilled with clean fill and reseeded. Analytica

  • Description: A trailer arrived to 165 and when the trailer was opened it was discovered that some fright had shifted in transit causing a small puncture to a carton on top of a pallet. The carton leaked within the box that was containing it but the material that leaked soaked into that box and at least one other nearby box. The leak is contained to the pallet and nothing hit the trailer floor. Safety advised CURA would be contacted for remediation and advised the crew could be set up for straight time Monday morning. ~The operations supervisor sent photos which showed the boxes contained bottles, not carto ns. Updated package type.

  • City: ANAHEIM
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On June 14, 2025, two (2) 30-gallon drums of UN2014 were crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and tires of the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the impacted site. Crews neutralized the product then containerized the damaged drum into one (1) 95-gallon overpack. PES utilized absorbent wipes and degreaser to further remediate the site. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: ABF stated that while a forklift operator was moving the commodity it had fallen off the skid, resulting in the spill. Following a site assessment, FCE personnel noted approximately 2-quarts released to the trailer interior and pail cardboard container. FCE collected the damaged 1-quart pails and co ntainerized them into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal. FCE personnel deployed absorbents, absorbent pads and utilized hand tools to scrape up material. All insulation impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 15-gallon pail for future terminal disposal. FCE personne l noted no further actions required on-site and crews demobilized at approximately 9:00 a.m. CDT.~

Upon the contractorâs arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the concrete dock and estimated that two (2) quarts of material was released due to improper packing of one (1) 275-gallon poly IBC. No absorbents were needed because all of the spilled products had evaporated by the time the contractors arrived. Clean Harbors personnel located the cracked tote and began setting up for a tote transfer. One (1) 275-gallon poly IBC tote was generated from the tote transfer. One (1) drum of waste was generated containing cut up tote pieces and absorbents. The generated waste will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight Lines team to coordinate disposal

  • City: NORRISTOWN

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâs arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the trailer floor and the concrete dock and estimated that fifty-five (55) gallons of material was released due to a forklift puncturing one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. Before Clean Harbors personnel arrived, the terminal had put down granular absorbents. The damaged drum was overpacked into one (1) 65-gallon metal drum. Two (2) 55-gallon metal drums were used to containerize the spent granular absorbents. ESTES approved of all cleanup and work done. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025060504
item.description:

  • City: DES MOINES
  • State: IA

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO ENTERPRISE SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 17:37 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release and tote transfer at terminal XDM. It was reported that approximately 40 gallons of Reax Complete released from one 265-gallon tote due to being strapped down. The release impacted trailer #4855008 and asphalt. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons UN3082 Reax Complete product released to the wooden trailer floor and to the asphalt due to improper loading. The contractors cleaned the spill using granular absorbents and generated (2) 55-gallon metal drums containing the absorbents and (2) 55-gallon poly drums containing the tote and impacted pallets. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The released material impacted the trailer floor and concrete below the trailer. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent material and containerized it into one (1) 5-gallon poly pail along with the damaged container. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freightâs contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On 6/12/2025 at 09:05 hours personnel in the CSXT Cumberland Yard discovered UTLX 679084, a Loaded tank car of Amines, Liquid, Corrosive, NOS, leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Taminco US (Eastman Chemical), was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-06120-0090). SPSI, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found 6 of 8 manway cover bolts less than tool tight. Contractor personnel secured the manway cover and decontaminated the exterior of the tank car. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipperâs representative- Melissa McCaslin.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0214 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal BNA. It was reported that approximately 8-oz of "Provox C (Sodium Carbonate Peroxhydrate)" released from a paper bag due to improper handling. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-ounces of UN3378 Provox C product released to the concrete dock floor due to improper loading. The contractors collected all released material and containerized product into a 30-gallon poly drum and placed impacted PPE and contaminated product into a 30-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 350-gallon metal tote due to a defective valve that resulted in the tote being leaking. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel performed a tote transfer to a new tote. They placed the remaining waste into one (1) 25-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freightâs contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: At 16:09 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release at a customer location in Lampasas, TX. It was reported that approximately 6 gallons of Acid Magic Multi-Use Formula released from one 275-gallon tote due to unknown reasons. The release impacted trailer #4355071. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 15-gallons of UN1760 Acid Magic Multi-Use Formula product released to entire wooden trailer floor and 15âx4â gravel area due to punctured by other freight. The tote was transferred and then cut up and put in (3) 55-gallon poly drums containing impacted debris, PPE and cut-up tote pieces. The waste was taken to the terminal and staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 12000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 07:38 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO (XSJ) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to a forklift incident, an unknown amount of 3M Furnace Black Acrylic Paint (hazardous - UN1993) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor. The terminal has requested a contractor out for cleanup and containment due to the size and type spill. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons UN1993 3M Furnace Black Acrylic Paint product released to wooden trailer floor due to forklift puncture. The contractors used paint thinner, hotsy and regular pressure washer on the trailer floor. The waste was containerized into 55-gallon metal drum contains product, absorbent pads and trash from trailer floor, (1) 55-gallon metal drum contains wash water, product and paint thinner. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-11
  • City: ARKADELPHIA
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 310000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: A Veolia truck was transporting a roll off box of residual incinerator ash from Veolia, Port Arthur, Texas to the Veolia, Gum Springs, AR landfill for disposal. While travelling around a curve on Highway 26 near the 300 block the vehicle veered out of its designated travel lane and onto the right shoulder. The driver then over corrected to the left, causing the vehicle to overturn onto its right side. During the incident, the hazardous materials container detached from the vehicle and released its contents onto the roadway, shoulder, and adjacent ditch. In addition, the truck leaked diesel fuel, hydraulic fluid, and other hazardous substances into the ditch. The Veolia driver was transported to the hospital via ambulance and was released shortly after with minor injuries.

  • Description: Vehicle owned by Pilot Travel Centers LLC (PTC) was exiting I-283 onto I-83N, when another vehicle made a sudden lane change from the left and struck the PTC tractor. As a result, the trailer shell was breached and approximately 4000 gallons of diesel fuel were released. Video of event was captured by in-cab cameras equipped on PTC vehicle.

  • Description: At 1831 EDT on 6/9, XPO-BNA contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 2 cups of Lead Battery Acid from 4x 80lb batteries on a trailer. The batteries were improperly loaded and damaged at BNA. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller, and although the terminal can clean the spill, the caller stated that their SCM, Dana Boles, had approved their request for contractor assistance. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-cups of UN2794 Lead Battery Acid product released to a 4âx4â area of the wooden trailer floor, steel grate on trailer floor and concrete beneath trailer due to improper loading. The contractors overpacked the battery into a 30-gallon poly drum and impacted absorbents were placed into 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report X-2025070006
item.description:
Report X-2025070006

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-08
  • City: LATHROP
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS LATHROP CALIFORNIA FACILITY, A THERMAL BATTERY EVENT OCCURRED WITH ONE AIR PACKAGE CONTAINING LITHIUM ION BATTERIES. IT WAS REPORTED THAT CONTENTS OF A PACKAGE EXPLODED INSIDE FEEDER TRAILER 180646 DURING THE TRAILER UNLOAD.THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO THE EVENT.AN OUTSIDE RESPONDER CLEANED UP THE DEBRIS PLACING PACKAGE AND ALL CONTENTS IN A 55-GALLON DRUM FOR DISPOSAL. THE PACKAGE CONTAINED THIRTY CYLINDRICAL SHAPED RECHARGEABLE LITHIUM-ION BATTERY CELLS, RATED AT 116.4 WATT HOUR PER CELL. THE OUTER BOX WAS APPROPRIATELY MARKED AND LABELLED WITH APPLIED DANGEROUS GOODS SHIPPING PAPERS. THE PACKAGE WAS OFFERED AIR SERVICE AND HAD PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY PRIOR TO THE THERMAL EVENT. THE PACKAGE WAS NOT TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR NETWORK. A REPORT WAS MADE TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER ON 01-JULY-2025, NRC REPORT 1435714. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM CALIFORNIA USING UPS ACCOUNT 55R5E9, RIVIAN AUTOMOTIVE LLC, 41100 PLYMOUTH RD, PLYMOUTH MI 48170.

  • Description: On 6/7/2025 at 20:43 hour, personnel in the CSXT Cumberland Yard reported PROX 44177, a residue tank car of Petroleum Distillates NOS, leaking from the top area of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Centennial Energy, was notified via CHEMTREC Report # 2025-0613-00. SPSI, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the car to leaking vapors due to a faulty vacuum relief valve. Contractor personnel removed the faulty vacuum relief valve and installed a blind closure to stop the product release. The car was held pending further repair by a certified shop or OTMA. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipperâs representative- Brian Newcome (303-597-5678).

  • Description: At 0358 EDT on 6/7, XPO-UDV contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 8 gallons of "AQUANOMIC 2.0 LOW TEMP LAUNDRY BUILDER" from a 15-gallon poly drum onto the trailer floor. The drum was punctured due to poor loading by LDA. The material is a class 8 corrosive, and ERTS will dispatch a contractor to assist with the spill. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 20-gallons of UN1824 Aquanomic 2.0 Low Temp Laundry Builder product released to an area of the wooden trailer floor and concrete dock floor due to a puncture from forklift or damaged pallet while in transit. The crew used granular absorbents to clean the impacted area and overpacked the damaged pails into (2) 55-gallon poly drums, (3) 55-gallon poly drums contains impacted absorbents, 55-gallon poly drum contains contaminated PPE. The waste was staged onsite for terminal to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-05
  • City: LATHROP
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On June 5, 2025, four (4) 55-gallon drums of Hurricane (UN2922) fell off the lift gate and released approximately 80-gallons of product to the ground and storm drain. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized granular absorbents, an absorbent boom, degreasing agent, and a pressure washer to remediate the site. All rinsate was containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums. One (1) emptied drum was containerized in one (1) 95-gallon overpack for disposal. The crew had to return to the site to at a later date to gain access to the impacted storm drain. On June 11, 2025, crews returned to the site. The outflow from catch basin was dammed with absorbent boom. Vacuum truck was mobilized to the outlet of the drainage pipe in preparation for collection during flushing activities. One (1) jet vacuum was utilized to flush the drain line pipe and all impacted rinsate was collected and containerized into one (1) vacuum truck for disposal.

  • Description: At 0424 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at UKC. It was reported that approximately 1 gallon of Desmodur 1 was released from one or maybe two 55-gallon DMs due to improper packaging by the shipper. The caller stated that it looks like there is a crack at the bottom of the drum and maybe two drums are damaged. The release impacted trailer #3194091 at dock door 100. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of UN2290 Desmodur 1 product was released to the entire area of the wooden due to improper packaging. The contractors cleaned the impacted trailer floor with granular absorbents. The (2) 55-gallon metal drums were overpacked into (2) 85-gallon metal drums and (2) 55-gallon poly drums contain impacted absorbents and pallet pieces. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: At 0028 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at BCH. It was reported that approximately 5 gallons of battery acid released from a 2105-pound commercial battery due to improper loading and blocking and bracing by terminal BGB. The release impacted trailer # 3233736 and the concrete under the trailer at dock door 136. Absorbents and noodles have been placed to prevent migration to the drains. Mike stated that Dion with Clean Harbors already agreed to assist with the cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of UN2794 Battery Acid released to the wooden trailer floor and concrete dock floor due to improper loading / blocking & bracing. The contractors cleaned and neutralized the trailer floor and concrete dock floor and transferred the products to new pallets. The waste was containerized to (4) 55-gallon poly drums with battery acid and impacted soda ash and (1) 275-gallon tote with battery acid and impacted rinse water. The 2100-pound battery was placed on a skid. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: t 20:28 PM ET, with BCH contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer in Chicago Heights, IL. The spill consists of approximately half a gallon of Zep Industrial Purple Degreaser & Cleaner, which was released from 4-1-gallon plastic jugs due to other freight being double stacked on top of the containers, crushing them and spilling onto the trailer floor. ERTS will dispatch a contractor to assist, as this is a corrosive material. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately .5-gallon of UN3266 Zep products released to a 1âx1â area of the wooden trailer floor due to improper loading. The contractors cleaned and neutralized with Simple Green and oil dry. The (2) bottles of Zep Industrial Purple Degreaser & Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (3) bottles of Zep Neutral pH Floor Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (4) bottles of Zep All Purpose Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (3) bottles of Zep House and Siding Pressure wash were placed in a 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted oil dry and PPE were containerized to a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: A declared dangerous goods shipment of UN1814, Potassium Hydroxide Solution, Packing Group III was involved in a forklift incident during sort operations at the Federal Express hub in Indianapolis, IN. The outer fiberboard packaging contained two intermediate fiberboard boxes containing two 2L plastic inner containers each. After damaging both the outer and one of the intermediate packagings, one of the plastic inner containers was punctured by the forklift, spilling its entire contents. The product spilled was from Roche Diagnostics, product name âCleanCell Mâ (part #: 04880293190). The outer box did have proper dangerous goods markings and labeling, and an accurate Shippers Declaration for Dangerous Goods was offered with the shipment. The shipment was placed in a salvage drum for containment and is being held pending further disposition instruction.

The release impacted trailer # 3193150 and the concrete outside at dock door 191. Oil dri was placed for containment. Mike stated that it has gone into the drain that goes to the retention pond. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of UN2815 Ancamine AEP product released to a 150âx100â area impacting the wood trailer floor, concrete underneath trailer and storm drain/retention pound due to a forklift puncture. The team used a skid vac to containerize approximately 2 to 3 gallons of residual product from the drain. This waste was solidified and containerized inside one of the (10) 55-gallon poly drums along with spent absorbent and debris. The team overpacked (1) 55-gallon poly drum into a 95-gallon poly drum. The waste was stated onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report X-2025061338
item.description:
Report X-2025061338

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-02
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Operations Supervisor I Jonathan Santos contacted safety to report a Hazardous Spill. Jonathan stated trailer 571577 was on the string pad in the 042/CAR yard when they noticed that it was leaking. Jonathan stated they attempted to open the door and roughly 6-gallons leaked out of the trailer and on to the yard. Jonathan stated he closed the door to keep the spill from getting worse on the yard. Jonathan stated two PROs were loaded onto trailer 571577, PRO 352225899 and PRO 051871342. PRO 352225899 was (30) 55-gallon drums of UN1866, Resin Solution, Flammable, 3, PG III and PRO 051871342 was (1 0) 1,200-lb Gaylords of flakes NOI, Granules, Lumps, Pellets, powder or Solid Mass, CL 60. It was determined that PRO 352225899 was leaking inside the trailer and onto the trailer floor. Jonathan stated that he was unsure the cause of the spill quantity that spilled. Jonathan stated that the trailer was loaded on 06/1/2025 at 13:24 (EST) at Dock Door 143. Jonathan stated that he did not see any spillage on the yard outside dock door 143 but he did see spillage on the 610 spot were it was staged before it was moved to the string pad. No storm drains or waterways were reported impacted by the re lease. Safety contacted CURA and spoke with Reagan Cowdrey for remediation. Safety requested that CURA provide the cause of the spillage and the spilled quantity. *ggattis* The cleanup crew stated the drum was punctured by a forklift while loading.

The debris punctured the driver side diesel fuel tank. Approximately 75 gals of diesel fuel was released through the puncture in the tank. This release occurred in less than 10 minutes.   • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0937 EST, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal XRY. It was reported that approximately 2) 1 gallon poly jugs of Aqua Balance UN1789 Hydrochloric acid, solution released due to forklift puncture. The release impacted trailer # 4653789. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of UN1789 Aqua Balance Muriatic Acid product released to the wooden trailer floor due to forklift puncture. The impacted areas of the floor were treated with the Kolor Safe Acid Neutralizer and generated (3) 85-poly drums containing damaged product, rags, absorbents and PPE. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Supervisor Peter Kostenko contacted Safety to report a spill on the dock involving UN1133 Adhesives, Class 3, Packing Group II, ERG 128. Peter stated that the container appeared to have been damaged by other freight being moved across the dock floor. He mentioned that he would investigate to identif y the forklift operator responsible for moving the skid into the pail, which caused the spill. Approximately 64 oz of product was spilled from a 5-gallon pail onto the dock floor. Safety advised that CURA would be contacted to assist with the cleanup and disposal of the damaged pail. GES personnel p laced the one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail into one (1) poly liner, and all cleanup debris was collected and containerized into one (1) other poly liner; both poly liners went into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was labeled as hazardous and staged in the terminal's waste holding room. With approval of the site contact, Peter, crews secured the scene and demobilized.

  • Description: At 21:42 PM ET, USA contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer in Sacramento, CA. The spill consists of approximately half a gallon of Cetguard Thixo, which released from 3 1-gallon metal cans due to excessive freight stacked on top of the cans, crushing them and causing them to spill onto the trailer floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the terminal, and it was determined a contractor will be needed as a chemical respirator is required for cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-cups of UN1263 Cetcguard Thixo product released to the wooden trailer floor due to a load shift. They used absorbents to clean up and generated (1) 55-gallon metal drum containing spent absorbents and impacted debris. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report X-2025070652
item.description:
Report X-2025070652

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-28
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 35000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 05-28-2025 a CN transportation employee observed a white liquid running down the side of tank car UTLX 682906 (loaded/UN 2215/Class 8 PG III) while performing switching operations at the CN Baton Rouge Yard in Baton Rouge, LA. Emergency notification was made to the CN Dangerous Goods Team, who responded to the incident. The CN Dangerous Goods Officer noted a significant amount of solidified white product on the sides of the tank car emanating from within the closed protective housing upon arrival. The protective housing was found to be completely full of solidified product, with a small stream of liquid still leaking, making it impossible to locate the origin of the leak. The manway cover swing bolts were loosened in order to relieve the internal pressure, which stopped the leak. The solidified product from within the protective housing was removed by use of a pneumatic chipping hammer and hot water pressure washer. All fittings within the protective housing were found to be secure. As the car was no longer leaking, it was impossible to determine the origin of the leak. The car remains in hold at the Baton Rouge Yard until the shipper receives an FRA OTMA 1 to have the car returned to the shippers' facility in Geismar, LA.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 27, 2025, Approximately 50-gallons diesel were released to the concrete and asphalt due to a fuel. overfill, while offloading. The release impacted asphalt and concrete on their tank pad. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. A clean up contractor (Hepaco of Birmingham, AL) responded to the site to conduct cleanup activities. Absorbent material was applied the affected concrete and asphalt, using hand tools to spread and ensure absorption. The saturated absorbents were collected and containerized into (2) 55-gallon drums that were transported off site for proper disposal. On June 13, 2025, two 55-gallon drums containing non-hazardous solid waste, (diesel impacted absorbents and boom), were accepted at Clean Harbors of Chattanooga, TN for proper disposal. This was a one-time event, that was an immediate release, due to human error. Clean-up activities were completed the same day. This release has been completely remediated, and no evidence was found that suggests any significant environmental impact remains on site.

  • Description: At 15:54 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release at a customer location in Chaska, MN. It was reported that approximately 5 gallons of Vanilla Extract released from one 5-gallon pail due to being punctured by the customer while unloading the trailer. The release impacted trailer #4632581. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of UN1197 Vanilla Extract product released to a 40âx6â area of the trailer floor and the asphalt lot below due to forklift puncture. The contractors used absorbents for cleanup and overpacked the waste and damaged pail and restacked the pallet for shipping. There were (2) poly drums, (1) 5-gallon and (1) 30-gallon. They used a degreaser to help bring up as much product as possible. The waste was taken off site and staged at vendors office for disposal.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7438
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâs arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted two areas of trailer floor with the dimensions a 3 ft x 3 ft and 1 ft x 2 ft and estimated that one (1) gallon of material was released due to a puncture in one (1) poly tote. Clean Harbors performed a tote transfer to one (1) 275-gallon poly tote and two (2) 55-gallon poly drums that was sent on to the customer. The contractor neutralized the trailer floor that was impacted. Clean harbors removed a 4' by 5' area of flooring for repair. They cut up the damaged tote and cage containerizing it into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums. Two (2) flex bins with cut up tote and wood were also generated. The waste was staged onsite, and ESTES approved of cleanup activities. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • City: SO PORTLAND

  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: One 05/22/2025, at approximately 13:05 hours, an FRA inspector at the CSX yard in Portland, Maine, discovered tank car GATX 201284, load of Liquefied Petroleum Gas, was leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Blue Racer Midstream, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-05-22-0012). Additionally, the South Portland Fire Department and Maine Department of Environmental Protection were notified. Fire department personnel responded and found the cause of the release was the tank carâs Liquid line valve was partially open and the secondary securement plug was less than tool tight. Fire department personnel closed the valve to stop the release. HEPACO, a CSX emergency response contractor, was also dispatched to the incident to conduct a secondary inspection and ensure the car was properly secured for transportation. The issue was identified, and corrective actions, were communicated to the shipperâs representative

  • Description: AN EMPLOYEE CAME WITH MANAGEMENT EXPERIENCING IRRITATION ON IS SKIN FROM A WET PACKAGE. HE WAS DIRECTED TO RINSE THE AFFECTED AREA WITH WATER. RESPONDER DONNED PPE; BOOTS, GLOVES, GOGGLES AND APRON AND TOOK FULLY STOCKED PRE TRIPPED SPILL CART TO THE SCENE. USING WORD OF MOUTH, SECURED A 15-FOOT HOTZONE AND USED DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET TO CLEAN AND CONTAINERIZE THE SPILL FOR TRANSPORTATION AND PROCESSING IN THE DMP. RESPONDER WAS INFORMED LATER THE EMPLOYEE DROVE HIMSELF TO THE HOSPITAL, MEDICAL CENTER DALLAS.

  • City: RUSSELL
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 2
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 200000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On May 20th, 2025, at 0609 hours, personnel in the CSXT Russell Yard discovered PROX90809, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia, leaking from the top of car. The car was isolated and the shipper, PCS Sales Inc., was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #0520-2025-00044). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found ammonia vapor actively releasing from the pressure relief valve (PRV). Additional response personnel installed a Midland capping kit over the leaking PRD to contain the release. The car was then trans-loaded, nitrogen purged, and prepped for home shop. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipperâs representative- Matt Paynter (706-564-8118).

  • Description: Hilco driver checked tank for water prior to loading, but failed to detect a small amount of water (improper preparation for transport). Driver loaded the hot asphalt product and left the facility. Roughly 20 minutes into his trip he noticed steam coming from the top of the trailer and immediately pulled over. As the steam came out of the vent pipe it siphoned product with the steam creating a boil over. Product did boil over for a few minutes and created a small spill of less than 25 gallons.

item.title: Report I-2025060173
item.description:
Report I-2025060173

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-08
  • City: MILWAUKEE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 5/8/2025 at 1:50 PM, Canadian Pacific Kansas City Railroad (CPKC) Hazmat Department became aware that FRA Inspector Daniel Perkins had performed a hazmat inspection at the CPKC Milwaukee, WI rail yard. During the inspection, Mr. Perkins detected an odor upon opening the protective housing cover on residue tank car FURX 134030. Mr. Perkins also detected a hissing sound coming from the B-end liquid valve assembly plug region. Mr. Perkins turned the B-end liquid valve handle approximately one inch in the closed direction. The hissing noise gradually ended, and the detected odor began to dissipate. Additionally, Mr. Perkins found the A-end liquid valve plug, and vapor valve plug less than tool tight. A railroad qualified response contractor was mobilized to correct any defects. The A-end liquid valve plug, and vapor valve plug were secured tool tight. All other closures were verified to be properly secured. The shipper was notified and instructed to obtain an OTMA-1 to move the FURX 134030 to home shop for requalification. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Description: The 5 gallon carboy was loaded onto a trailer on a wooden pallet with 3 other carboys containing the same material. A nail on the pallet puncured the bottom of one carboy and a slow drip with a puddle of accumulated waste on the pavement under the trailer was recognized by Ingenium personnel around 8:30 am. Once the spill was recognized, Ingenium personnel donned appropriate PPE and used the absorbent contents of a nearby spill kit to barricade the spilling material and soak up the contents. The involved carboy was turned away from the puncture hole to stop contents from exiting container. Once under control, the contents of the punctured carboy were carefully poured into a new carboy and labeled for transportation. The contents used for the spill cleanup were placed in a 55 gallon poly drum and profiled for disposal.

item.title: Report I-2025060218
item.description:
Report I-2025060218

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-01
  • City: Calgary
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: SAMARITAN'S PURSE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The generator was properly prepared for shipment, and the 59-gallon tank was confirmed to contain less than a quarter tank of diesel fuel. The generator was loaded onto the upper deck of the DC-8 combi aircraft without incident. At 0659 local time, during aircraft rotation from Calgary International Airport (CYYC), approximately 1-2 gallons of fuel vented from the installed vent on top of the fuel tank over a 30-second period. The fuel spilled onto the aircraft pallet, and due to the aircraft's pitch during takeoff, it drained underneath the bulkhead and onto the cabin carpet. The captain was immediately notified, and a fire extinguisher was brought to the pallet position. A spill kit was used to absorb the excess fuel. The captain promptly decided to return to CYYC and landed at 0742 local. After blocking in, passengers were unloaded, and aircraft doors were opened to vent any fumes. All upper-deck cargo, including the generator, was offloaded. A Canadian Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) representative met the aircraft and spoke with the captain. The representative directed the removal of contaminated carpet areas and the cleaning of the aircraft floor by a certified aircraft cleaner, which began shortly after. Inspections were conducted on both the upper and lower decks by an aircraft mechanic, with no damage found on the upper deck and no leakage found on the lower deck.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 429110
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 5, 2025, at 7:17 PM MST Facility operations personnel began discharging rail cars of denatured ethanol into a header which was believed to deliver product to the Facility tank farm for product storage. A total of six (6) railcars were connected to an approximately 1900 foot incomplete, under construction product header which contained an open 12" flange with dust cap, and thirteen (13) open piping elbows. At 8:49 PM MST Facility operators discovered the release along the incomplete product header and shutdown unloading pumps and closed valves on product railcars by 9:01 PM MST. Over the 1.5-hour period, a total of 82,431 gallons of denatured was released across an approximately 730' section of the product header from the six (6) railcars that were connected. The denatured ethanol impacted the underlying ballast and migrated to the West and South of the direct spill area to low-lying areas on the leased property and the Burlington Northern & Santa Fe (BNSF) Railroad property.

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-01
  • City: TICONDEROGA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: GENOX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: While removing an empty trailer from customer site, GenOx Driver failed to disconnect safety (whip check) lanyards resulting in hose post (Customer side piping) being pulled down and broken creating a leak of natural gas. Approximately 490,000 SCF was released. Upon notification, Natural Gas decompression skids were remotely emergency stopped, and maintenance technicians dispatched. Upon arrival, NG Advantage Maintenance technicians were able to secure the leak using remote shutoff features on the CNG Trailers. Area was monitored and gas was determined to have disbursed. Piping was isolated and repairs were scheduled and completed at a later date. Note: This was a failure of onsite piping causes by movement of a trailer. At no time did the hazardous material packaging (trailer) fall.

item.title: Report I-2025060066
item.description:
Report I-2025060066

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-09
  • City: CENTER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Central Arkansas Petroleum Transport, Inc
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 35593
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On December 9th, 2024, at approximately 1700, Tyson began refueling procedures for the above ground storage tank. The receiving tank began to overfill due to operator error. Immediately, the Tyson spill response team started laying down absorbent socks around the storm drain and then poured a load of chicken feed to act as an absorbent / berm around the affected area. The diesel fuel was contained on the concrete, but approximately 50 gallons of fuel was in the rock bed surrounding the fuel tank. A hazardous response team (Hopkins Wrecker Service) was notified and arrived on scene at approximately 1830. Hopkins Wrecker Service put down additional dry sweep and absorbent socks. Next, Hopkins used a bobcat to pick up the absorbents, placed them in a lined dumpster, and cleared the soil. A review of the storm water outfall showed zero signs of an oil sheen and no smell was present. There were no off-site impacts from this release. No personnel were harmed and/or injured. At the time of release, the weather was partly cloudy, and the wind was blowing from the south at 8 mph. The temperature was 70Â°F and the humidity was 68%.

item.title: Report I-2025070019
item.description:
Report I-2025070019

  • City: GONZALES

  • Carrier/Reporter: CHEMTRADE HOLDCO US INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On December 2nd , 2024 Driver Manager was called by driver, Eddie Esqueda, and informed that less than 0.5 gallon of Aluminum Sulfate Solution (AL Clear A7 Bulk) overflowed out the top of a customer tank due to a customer aligned, customer system, valve misalignment. The customer acknowledged full responsibility and immediately cleaned up the product. No product left containment and spilled only onto the concrete surrounding the tank. The customer immediately cleaned the small spill up and corrected the valve misalignment to facilitate the continued offloading into the correct customer tank. Driver manager instructed the driver to call and report the incident to Chemtrec to ensure documentation and trigger internal and external reporting of the event. Only when the PHMSA notification was received was the company aware the NRC number had been called and reporting had not been completed.

item.title: Report I-2025060067
item.description:
Report I-2025060067

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-25
  • City: Elk Grove
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Sacramento Area Sewer District (previously Sacramento County Regional Sanitation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2900
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Thatcher arrived at the EchoWater Facility of the Sacremento Area Sewer District with the shipment of Sodium Bisulfite 40% and began offloading into the storage tank at approximately 07:30. The delivery was left unattended by the operator from EchoWater, during which time the tank overfilled and began spilling into secondary containment. Staff in the Process Control Center (PCC) observed unusual tank levels and called the operator who then returned to the offload station and discovered the spill. The operator manually shut down the offload pump, switched tanks, and then called the spill into the PCC at 08:23. The tank released for approximately 20 minutes before mitigation. Several factors were identified as contributing to the tank overfill system failing. Most critically, a programming error disabled the automatic shutdown feature of the offloading pumps from a high/high level alert while the pump was in local/manual operation mode. Another programming error resulted in the PCC receiving both the high and high/high level alarms as yellow when the high/high should elevate to red. Additionally, the priming water was left on and the cross connects between the tanks were closed, increasing the fill rate and leaving the solution nowhere to go but to spill into secondary containment. Once the release was stopped, the spilled material was returned to process as permitted by its waste characterization. Waste characterization for a spill from the tank itself is based on a 20% solution since product is received at 40% and diluted to 20% for use/storage at this location. There was no release from the packaging or offloading equipment, only from the overfilled tank.

item.title: Report I-2025060064
item.description:
Report I-2025060064

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-05
  • City: CHANNELVIEW
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EQUISTAR CHEMICALS, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 80000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On September 5, 2024, at around 9:35 AM, approximately 14,200 lbs of Ethyl-aluminum dichloride 15% in Hexane ("EADC" herein) were released from the liquid product discharge valve of a tank trailer during a routine unloading operation at the Product Flexibility Unit Unloading Rack. Infrared hydrocarbon detectors detected the released hexane and automatically activated the area deluge system, which suppressed the hydrocarbon vapors and ultimately washed the material into the process sewer collection system, where it was successfully impounded and neutralized prior to discharging. Site emergency response personnel entered the deluged area and stopped the release by closing the air actuated product discharge valve on top of the tanker, which had been found in the open position and not connected to the unloading boom arm. The investigation identified failed barriers and causes leading to the incident and determined that theloading operator had deviated from the unloading procedure by connecting the pressurizing nitrogen to the tanker and actuating air to the product discharge valve, prior to connecting the product unloading boom arm to the trailer. Emergency response personnel found the pneumatic switch for the air actuated product discharge valve in the "OPEN" position, however, the investigation team was not able to conclusively determine how or why the valve was opened. The pneumatic switch for the valve in the "OPEN" position allowed the pressurized EADC to flow to atmosphere. Following interviews with other qualified EADC unloading operators, the investigation team determined that the individual responsible for unloading this trailer deviated from the well-established unloading procedure used in practice. Corrective actions were generated with the intent of addressing the failed barriers and the underlying causes of these failures. The investigation team concluded that while the loader violated well-established and understood safe unloading procedures, the written language of the EADC unloading procedure is unclear and contains unworkable steps due to the above mentioned out of service system.

item.title: Report I-2025060053
item.description:
Report I-2025060053

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-28
  • City: LAPLACE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DENKA PERFORMANCE ELASTOMER LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 15:55 hours on August 28, 2024, a contract employee was moving a pallet with 4 drums of Isom Purge Wastewater using a fork truck. One of the drums tipped and fell off the pallet onto the ground. The drum was closed with a ring and a lid; however, the drum was not sufficiently secured to the fork truck per site procedure. This incident resulted in a spill of approximately 15 gallons to the ground and lasted for approximately 5 minutes before it was secured. The Isom process contains 1,4-dichlorobutene. Calculations indicate that the 1 lb. reportable quantity was exceeded as a result of this spill. Calls were placed with the NRC, LSP, and SJBP Emergency Response beginning at approximately 16:50 hours on August 28, 2024 notifying of this incident. The amount of 1,4-dichlorobutene that was released is estimated to be 3 lbs. The Isom Purge Wastewater spilled to the ground inside the fenceline. The contaminated soil was removed and containerized the same day the spill occurred. There was no emergency condition associated with this incident and no off-site impact reported due to the spill. No site personnel were injured or required medical treatment as a result of this incident.
